I dunno if I agree with that. Although its comforting, there's a wobble effect that takes place even in a balanced spin. When a top is spun, it spins until friction gets the better of its angular momentum. At that point, the top wobbles a few times then straightens back briefly, then wobbles even more again until friction and gravity wins.
So while Earth may not flip, angular momentum will eventually lose its battle against friction and cause Earth to wobble.

Couldn't one also argue with the conservation laws?: Because the energy E and the angular momentum L has to be concerved and E=L²/2J, the absolute value of the moment of inertia J of the current axis has to be constant.
In case the moment of inertia is at a non-degenerated extremum (1st and 3rd axis of a rigid body), there is only this one momentum that has the current energy. So there is no possibility to change the axis without changing the angular momentum or the energy. These axis must therefore be stable.
But in case of the 2nd axis there are different axis that have the same moment of inertia, so the rotation axis can change and will change if there are any deviations.

This also explains why the water-filled bottle has only one stable axis: Now, the rotational energy is not constant anymore but can reduce due to friction. Therefore, the argument from above is not valid for the 3rd axis anymore and only the 1st axis will be stable.

Seems like an unbalanced gyroscope. So as the masses are spun, and the centrifugal force interacts with the other masses, from the other axes, the action is to balance. It needs a full rotation, or even a half one to create the motion of continuing its movement, throwing the body during the least interactive mass's spin. So that the balance can happen in one moment. Once the movement to intermediarily become balanced, the shifting begins again. Like a binary counter. the large mass keeps changing at the 0 bit, and the 1 bit changes, and as my analogy tells, the largest bit, is the least mass. Because it is has less controlling mass, but it will eventually be part of the movement.

Given that the earth has stabilized and is at most wobbling currently, how much mass would need to shift around for it to need to rebalance? Would things like tectonic plate shifting and (really) large scale volcano eruptions be able to shift the weight distribution enough to cause a new rebalancing?

The centrifugal force occurs due to momentum. The weight of whatever traveling in a circle has velocity, and wants to travel in a straight line, but its forced to go around in a circle. It is constantly getting pulled towards the center (by structural strength of what ever is spinning) changing the direction of the chunk’s velocity vector to be tangent to its path. If it where to rip off and fly away, the chunk would spin on its center of g at same rpm as whatever thing it was ridding and travel in straight line which happens to be tangent to the circle it was going around in, right where it broke off. Very related to this is gyroscopic stuff, and also, orbital mechanics.

Not to mention, you can aim a sling if you know this stuff.

Well let's see. In free fall on a space station, what we observe, while in the space station, is limited by its size, so, the full effect cannot be seen. Neither can it be seen inside one of those close to free fall plane rides.

What this wing nut is, obviously, proving, is simple. When you undo a normal screw, wing nut, bottle top, it's anti clockwise. Clockwise to do it back up again. When the wing nut was unscrewed and alliwed to free fall continue its flight, it came off spinning anti clockwise. As it proceeded across the room, in its own imperfect way, it was doing what a gyroscope does on Earth. Consider a spinning gyroscope. You can put it on a table then pull the top down to a little above flat and let it go. With the spinning wheel oart spinning over the edge of the table, hitting nothing, the gyroscope remains as is until interfered with or rotation drops off enough. The only thing anchoring it to the table is the small bit upon which it was standing, down the centre of its pole. While spinning off at an angle, push the top of it down far enough and it drops off to the floor and keeps spinning but if you started the gyroscope spinning clockwise (right handed people normally do) and then caused it to fall by pushing the top down too far off the table, when it hits the floor, from your perspective looking down at it, it's now spinning anti clockwise. It, also, kanded with a heavier thud than if you had the same gyroscope, not spinning and dropped it on its point from the same height.

If the gyroscope is a perfect one, then because of the spin, you can see the rest of its weight doesn't matter, in the tests above until the top and bottom points are almist or actually the same height. The original point, on the table, gas lost enough spin point energy, diwn its shaft, to make it drop.

So, with that in mind, remember a wing nut is an imperfect simulacrum of a gyroscope but in free fall has advantages. Whwn it unscrews and flies off, it is building a minor spin point like a gyroscope does. Unfortunately, the only gyroscopes I have observed, have been on Earth. In space, the leading point of the spin shaft creates a spin point that would be happy not to flip over but unfortunately, the space station is orbiting Earth which is, itself, spinning. You may think, in free fall, on a space station, that there's no gravity. OK so what's holding the space ship in orbit so it doesn't shoot off into space? The effects of the soace station orbiting and Earth spinning, is enough to create something best visualised by looking from galactic north, outside our gakaxy, back down at it. See the arms? Earth spins mini versions of that, too. The wing nut with its spin point bubble hits a fronf like point of gravity emanating from Earth, is not powerful enough to bash through it and because this point of gravity is bent like the arms of a galaxy, the spin point gravity bobs down minutely enough to flip the wing nut over and then cause drag so that the wing nut doesn't revolve but apoears ro just flip and continue. Now the wing nut, originally spinning anti clockwise, is now spinning clockwise and cancels out the mini gravitic effect inside the tube and vegins making another at the leading edge if the spin. It hits another gravitic frond, flips the same and on it goes.

What I would like to see is the same wing nut released facing upwards or downwards (relatuve to Earth). It will hit a gravitic frond eventually but not likely to flip and repeat at the same rate as horizontally.

Simple, isn't it? BTW, that gyroscope on Earth. Make it out of superconductor material, super freeze it and spin it on top of a neodymium magnet for an interesting effect you may not have witnessed before.

OK. I'm at 6:20, he's planning to prove Richard Feynman wrong, and find an intuitive reason. The long T shaped handle has just been unscrewed and spun from the panel in the Space Station and flipped it's long axis several times.

Here it is...
It's been established that an object's spin will be stable if it spins on the long axis or the short axis, but will flip as it spins on it's medium axis. The reason, as the object spins around the shaft with the T crossbar handle rotating, if the shaft goes minutely off centre, centrifugal force will throw it outwards and away from the centre of rotation until it is perpendicular to the direction of spin, at this time inertia will cause the already moving shaft to continue away from it's original direction and flip to the other end where it will settle momentarily due to running out of inertia. A short time later the shaft will be thrown off centre again and flip back to it's original direction, where the process will repeat.

Now, carry on and see if that's what the video finds...

You must be familiar with the "Crookes radiometer." It does not store, nor dissipate energy, yet it spins indefinitely in the presence of radiation. The tennis racket is interacting with the stream of time, in the same way a physical body encounters gravity, near a larger body.

As the high moment of inertia axis pierces the time stream, all areas are equally affected, but the low moment of inertia axis gets "frame dragged," by the passage of time, which robs inertia from the high moment axis since it must drag the low axis along, or disintegrate, until finally an inertial tipping point is reached and the equation resets.

In fact, one could probably arrange these devices to provide a physical representation of the orientation and direction of the stream of time, a "Kellers chronometron," if you will, since chronometer is already taken and arguably, more mundane a term.

The more I think about it, the less satisfying this explanation is. First, no explanation can be truly intuitive if it relies on fictitious forces (that's a bit like using gods to explain natural phenomenon). Second, it doesn't actually explain anything. Let's adopt the rotating reference frame used in the explanation so centrifugal forces are exerted on the small masses in the z-direction. You then automatically say that these centrifugal forces accelerate the masses away from the y-axis, but why do they do? Why are these centrifugal forces not balanced by the centripetal component of the tension forces the same way the centrifugal forces on the large masses are? You seem to be begging the question: assuming the masses will accelerate to explain why they accelerate.

I can simplify this explanation significantly (in an inertial reference frame, no less): if the small masses are displaced slightly, the tension forces within the disk are not strong enough to prevent them from moving farther out away from the axis of rotation. As the masses move farther away from the axis of rotation, the tension forces increase. Thus, the tension forces within the disk act as a restoring force, producing oscillatory motion*.

While this cleans up the explanation you provided and removes the need to rely on fictitious forces, it does not address the key issue of explaining WHY the tension forces aren't strong enough to prevent the masses from moving outwards. My best guess for why that is ultimately comes down to the fact that nothing is really preventing the disk from rotating along that axis so the tension forces don't need to be that strong. If you think about the large masses, if the tension forces holding them in place were not large enough to produce the required centripetal acceleration then the only way for the large masses to move outwards is for the entire disk to break apart. Therefore the tension forces exerted on the large masses are as strong as they need to be to keep them rotating at a constant distance from the axis up to the point of mechanical failure of the disk. For the smaller masses, this is not the case. They can be moved farther away from the axis of rotation without destroying the disk simply by rotating the disk. And so that's what happens. The reason the tension force on these masses is maximum once they have rotated 90 degrees is precisely because they have reached the point where they can no longer move farther away from the axis of rotation without destroying the disk, so like the big masses they have reached a point where the maximum tension force exerted on them is the mechanical limit of the disk.

It's not a perfect explanation, but it's as close as I'm going to get without spending more time on this than I'm willing to at the moment.

Belated comment: Notice in the videos of each real object that the final spin direction and spin axis of the object always continue to be the same as the initial conditions, when seen in relation to our external fixed inertial frame. So, even if this did happen to a roughly spherical planet, that planet's spin would continue to align with all the other planets, but its topographical features (continents, etc.) would invert from north to south. We would not see Venus as spinning backwards or Uranus as spinning sideways, and Earth would definitely NOT spin clockwise in relation to solar north, as shown in the illustration at 10:13. Of course, on earth's surface we would reverse from west-to-east motion as north and south became reversed, a delta-V of up to 3,300 KpH. This could be something of a wild ride, depending on how fast it happened.

This is just a question, not a solution or a proof. This looks to me like a liberated, or unrestrained version of the twisting forces on the blades of a variable pitch aircraft propeller in flight. In a single engine aircraft, the control mechanism drives the blades towards coarse pitch and the centripetal forces created by the engine driven spin drives the blades towards fine pitch. This is because the weight in the leading and trailing edges are a bir farther away from the axis of rotation in this condition. The rotation towards fine pitch is of course limited by the fine pitch stop, but if the fine pitch stop didn’t exist, the blade pitch should oscillate between equal and opposite positive and negative blade angles if I disregard friction and aerodynamic effects. Blade angle is controlled by engine oil pressure, so if the oil pressure fails, the centrifugal blade twisting moment will twist the blades to fine,allowing the aircraft airspeed to spin up the engine rpm, helping the pilot to ‘bump start’ the engine. In a multi engine or a single engine aerobatic aircraft, there is a counterweight at right angles to the plane of the propeller blade so if there is a loss of oil pressure, the blades go to the feather position and the engine can stop, not being driven by the airspeed through the propeller.
So, is a variable pitch propeller a restrained version of this multi-axis spinning effect? I look forward to your thoughts, thank you.

The author of this video makes a very subtle error. For example, the disc doesn't necessarily go "back-and-forth" (ref. 9:26). Think of a rigid-bar pendulum being placed near the top of it's swing arc and RELEASED, vs. the same pendulum being placed near the top and PUSHED. The released one goes "back-and-forth" but the latter can go through the peak repeatedly. The animation at 9:20 shows an example of the latter, while the video author states the former.

NOOOOO! At 7:31 you mention "centripetal forces". THERE IS NO SUCH THING!!! Centripetal terms are kinematic effects; they arise from the acceleration expressions (omega x [omega x X]) and not from the force side of Newton2. And at 7:44 you mention "centrifugal forces". Dear Lord. You are my worst enemy! I just finished teaching a first year graduate course in 3d, particle and rigid body dynamics (in which we dealt extensively with multiple rotating reference frames) and you're casually - and incorrectly - talking about things these things, further sowing long-term confusion rather than elucidating facts about basic physics. By the way, a simple description of Euler's equations doesn't require any high-end mathematics (once you've taken all of the necessary derivatives) ... and can be used to explain what's going on. "So the earth won't flip - its spinning about the axis with the maximum moment of inertia".  That sounds like a simplied mathematicians explanation and didn't provide any evidence the earth can't flip. The earth is not an asteroid. It is a very dynamic elastic system with a molten core that has surges of molten movement, and plate tectonics that cause large bodies far from the center to migrate. Then there are shorter term effects such as the earth redepositing large amounts of moisture such as glaciers aroind the planet.  For example the polar ice sheet is currently  3km thick sure not much compared to the 12000km diameter of the earth but the point is the earth look relatively static in our human viewframe but it is far from static. Look at even the 3 gorges dam filling creating a momentary imbalance.  So I don't think a simple mathematical equation is even close the proving the earth can't flip.  Maybe we should try modeling more dramatic scenarios that prove that the earth actually could flip such as adding larger amounts of polar ice or extreme mountain buildup with plate tectonics causing 100,000m high mountains. So many variables to test. It may help explain a lot of things that happen on earth such as the geological time periods Cretaceous, Jurassic,  Triassic, Permian etc which almost occur with approximate regulariy. I shall make it my ambition to prove you wrong that the earth can't mathematically flip. Your math may be right at a snapshot in time but far too simple for something as complex as earth.

What I found fascinating was that Richard Feynman considered it impossible to solve this intuitively.
That tells you a lot about quantum physicists, for whom mathematics IS reality (and make errors because they think that everything possible in the mathematics they use in their models, is also possible in reality).
In fact, the thing is quite simple, and you don't have to be a mathematician to solve it, and although I was too lazy to stop the video and analyze the thing completely, the solution was immediately sketched in my mind as something caused by minuscule imperfections causing amplifying forces. From that point, all there was to do would have been to make a complete intuitive forces analysis, like in the video.

But while the tennis racket does the flip in just one turn around the first axis of (lowest) inertia, when rotated around the intermediate (second) axis of inertia, it would seem intuitively logical for me that even if you rotate it long enough around the lowest inertia axis (in space), a flip should eventually happen because it doesn't rotate around the axis of maximum inertia (third).

And now, as I type, I just I remembered the T-shaped object on 5:16, which rotates on its first axis and flips, and understood that the wing nut also rotates around the first, not the second one, like it does in the example of the tennis racket axis . The greatest the mass asymmetry along the first axis, the quicker the flip happens (I guess) when rotated around the first axis.
So mass asymmetric objects along the first axis, rotating around the first axis should flip, but the flip happens faster when rotating around the second axis (tennis racket example).

It would be interesting to see a tennis racket rotated in space around its second axis. Would it flip at each turn? Probably, but if rotated around its first axis, it would flip just like the T-shaped object or the wing nut.

In conclusion the intermediate axis theory and the Dzhanibekov effect are not exactly the same thing, because the wing nut and the T-shaped object did not rotate around the second, intermediate axis, but the first one.

Nice description.  However, I'm baffled that you've included "centrifugal force" in your answer.  No force is pushing outward on any of the masses.  The concept of centripetal/centrifugal force is one of the most common misconceptions in all of physics (the other probably would be Newton's 3rd Law, which is also incorrectly used in this video.) The term centripetal force actually refers to the sum of forces directed radially inward and is not in and of itself a force.  The concept of "micro-gravity" is another widely held misconception.  The gravitational field strength in low-earth orbit is on the order of 85-90% of the value on the surface of the earth - that's hardly microgravity.

Shouldn't rotation around the primary axis be subject to the same instability according to this explanation? Seems like something's still missing, no?

Edit: I found a math overflow explanation directly from Terry Tao that answers this exactly. To sum up, the Coriolis force on the large masses when rotating around the primary axis are significant enough to keep the spinning constrained to the primary axis. The Coriolis forces are negligible when spinning around the intermediate axis, so it flips.

TL;DR the Coriolis effect counteracts the centrigual effect when spinning on the primary axis. Around the intermediate axis, the Coriolis effect is not enough to prevent the flipping.

Since angular momentum has to be conserved (for no external torque) even a solid object spinning about either of its two principal axes, i.e. with the smallest and intermediate moments of inertia I1 and I2, will eventually flip and spin about its third principal axis with the largest moment of inertia I3 due to disipative forces within the object which will cause its kinetic energy to dampen over time (K = L^2 /2 x I3). Liquid filled objects do magnify an effect which is otherwise always present.

Think about drawing a "center-line" through the center of gravity of an object on each side to form the three axes. That experiment with the bottle of water actually proves a lot about why gravity on earth works:

At the start, they spin the bottle sideways and it twists like a ballerina. After a few seconds it starts to become unstable, and it shifts to the state of least resistance. If you look carefully when it does that, the axis it started spinning on is technically no longer actually spinning! The inertia from the spin is a part of the final rotational movement, but because that movement is extended over the whole object, rather than the object continuing to spin around that axis at the same rate, the spin is altered in the same way that the forces that caused the spin shift to ease the rotation of the object... It's actually amazing to see when you understand what's happening!

So why a rocket does not invert its spin axis, while a bolt does?
because the bolt has a larger base than the axis.
All the examples show this.
Geometry of the object is important here.
A rocket is thin and long, thus the secondary axes of rotation are ininfluent: their centrifugal force is nearly null in relation to the mass.
If you would add enough rotation though, it could invert its spin.

A sphere will never invert its spin axis.
The reason is easy: there is no secondary axis.
A disc example is the same.

Also, resonance is another factor to put in that was not considered at all in the video.
Especially for small objects, resonance is a major factor that would push the object to invert its axis of rotation by cumulating power on the secondary axis at each roll, when the conditions are met.

He doesn’t address why a perturbation in rotations about other axes doesn’t cause this phenomenon. It’s too hard to briefly explain in text, but the result is that you get precession, and variation of obliquity, which is what two of the milankovitch cycles are. The sun and the moon are the source of the nudges that perturb the earth, but you could remove them and it would continue to process and vary obliquity for some time until energy is dissipated like he discusses later on, just like how the T handle flips for quite a while. The reason that precession occurs and not a complete flip is exactly because location of the larger mass makes the response to the torque slower, so the tip of the top spirals in a small band instead of a near complete flip flop spiral.

9:00 you seem to walk right past the most important point here: an ideal object such as you're describing would NOT have the the centrifugal force: by definition, it is ideal, and perfect, and perfectly on the graph's axis, and thus feels no force. HOWEVER, in real life, no physical spinning object will have those light masses absolutely perfectly on the plane. THAT LACK OF PERFECT ALIGNMENT is what causes it to have a small force... and that small force moves it to where it has a bigger force... and so on and so on and so on until it is visibly moving and quite rapidly at that.

In the video of the spinning wing nut, the more perfect the plane of spin (and the wing nut's manufacturing tolerances) the longer it would be between flips. The more off-kilter, the faster the imbalance builds.

13:30 What you're really saying here is that the earth at one point may have been in the unstable state, but has already done its change to the most stable state, and it won't change from this point because of that. What you don't mention, and what I bet has some influence on this, is that the earth's rotation "flings out" the equator just a bit, which I believe is something like 50km or so farther away from the earth's center than the poles are (being 53 I learned this 45 years ago or so, not sure of the exact amount). So, this probably ensures that any planet that is rotating is probably already just enough disk-like that this rotation may suffice to make that plane of rotation the stable plane of rotation. Or in other words, if a heavenly body is spinning, that may suffice to make the plane of spin stable. (Your examples in the space station show bottles. But if you used a water balloon without even the filling nipple, I'd guess that if you started it spinning it'd expand around its equator, self-reinforcing that plane of spin. So while the rigid bottle changes planes, a flexible balloon--modelling the flexible earth crust with liquid magma underneath--wouldn't.)

In around 1960 the Quaker Oats Company gave away a plastic spinning toy in packets of their breakfast cereal Oat Crunchies.  It was a hollow sphere around one to one and a half inches in diameter, with one smallish part sliced off (imagine an apple placed on a chopping board, then with a straight motion you just slice away a chunk).  From the centre of the flat (circular) part protruded a short straight rod which was perpendicular to the flat surface.  This toy was actually a spinning top, and if you spun it fast by holding the "stalk" between finger and thumb and then set it down on a smooth surface with the stalk upright, after a while it would start to topple and then suddenly flip upside down, so it was now still spinning but standing on the "stalk".  When I was at University in the late 1960s reading Maths, we studied Intermediate Moments of Inertia and I finally understood what was going on.  I wish I could get one of those toys now - it fascinated me then and I know it would do so again!

Flip terminates with momentary stability, only to renew itself.  Earth will not flip as it's a sphere, as noted.  Greater shift of mass to one aspect of a 3-dimensional object has no choice but to flip in a 3rd path.  It is mass following the path of least resistance.  Dynamics to be viewed as proof of 3 dimensions, universal expansions along these paths.  Left to right, up to down, vice versa.  Now we see center-seeking force, straight line-seeking force, and balance-seeking force.  If an irregularly shaped object could be perfectly balanced (equal mass on 3 axes despite odd shape), it would never flip as it would be in proportion like a sphere.  The flipping tumble is the object's way of yielding to energy as it can only spin so much for so long at the other two axes.  Something has to give as unbalanced 3-dimensional objects can't maintain motion in only 2 planes.  If the mass doesn't shift, i.e., leave the one plane for another, the object must yield to motion along the 3rd dimension, remaining true to it's composition.

All good here, except his somewhat forced and self-comforting concluding remarks, without proof, that the Earth's current moment of inertia is sic. "stable" and unchanging.
"Stable" spinning orbits for a sphere in a vacuum is obviously dependent on the mass as well as the distribution of the mass within the sphere. The larger the mass the longer its "cycle" of "flipping". The tiny mass of the wing nut clearly shows in a cyclical frequency of only a few seconds. For a planetary size mass, such as the Earth, its quite possible the "flipping" cycle could be millions of years or more. Hence, "stable" is relative to the time-frame involved. It would still be "stable" from human civilizational perspective, if Earth's "flipping" frequency is say 10 million years each. The issue is we have no way to tell if the "flipping" is going to occur the day after tomorrow (pun intended) or a million years later; or if global climate change might melt the ice-caps and lead to accelerated change to the planet's moment of inertia due to changing mass distribution.

The instability of rotations about the intermediate axis is easily understood if one views the trajectories on the energy surface; see here:
https://thatsmaths.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/benderorszag-rigidbody.jpg?w=419&h=385

The figure is taken from Bender and Orszag, Advanced Mathematical Methods for Scientists and Engineers (a fabulous text, BTW).
If the angular velocity vector starts along the y-axis (the intermediate axis), since the fixed point there is a *saddle*, and therefore unstable, the angular velocity vector will move away exponentially at a rate determined by the largest positive eigenvalue of the saddle, given any arbitrarily small perturbation. Contrarily, rotations started about the 2 other axes are stable; small perturbations result in small oscillations about the fixed points. The lesson here is that qualitative analyses of ODES, through geometrical (phase space) techniques, can be a very powerful way to understand the dynamics of low-dimensional systems, without the need for complex analytic expressions, which do not yield much insight.

The Earth should never have been viewed as liable to flipping. First, the Earth's situation is not that of "big mass on one axis and small mass on another axis." Even the hex-nut in the ball of clay is far too severe a perturbation from the Earth's scenario. Second, the Earth is not a solid sphere: it has fairly-symmetrical internal components that are gummy (the mantle) and liquid (the core.) These components provide drag-effects and tidal-effects that absorb (i.e., covert to heat) the momentae that would, in these microscopic scenarios of highly-rigid objects (e.g., wing-nuts) result in the flip. Third, the tidal force of our Moon similarly dampens any tendency to move towards a flip. (August 31, 2020)  Copyright 2020 by the holder of this forum-handle: all rights reserved.

The conclusion that the earth's spin is stable is worth questioning.  The earth is not either a uniform body, nor is it a static body in terms of mass distribution.  It is, in fact, more in kind with a bottle filled with fluid - but a fluid (molten rock - magma, and both molten and solid iron core) quite viscous.  If the question is: "will the earth flip" as in North Pole-South Pole axis invert relative to the plane of circulation around the sun, the answer is a qualified no - but will other elements of the earth - the light continental crusts, drifting over the mantle and redistributing mass, the convective cells within the earth's outer core and mantle, and the instability introduced by the Milankovich forces - cause internal changes such as magnetic pole reversal.  Earth really can't be considered a solid, uniform body by a long stretch.  We have abundant and undeniable evidence of both continental drift and of frequent magnetic pole reversals over recent (thousands of years) history, embedded in the rock forming either side of the ridges on the sea floor - illustrating both the instability of the earth's mass distribution and the consequences on the magnetic polarity of the dynamo that is the earth's heart.  It would be interesting to know if the phenomenon described in this video is in any way connected with the pole reversals we've seen - and on life on earth, such as bird migrations that are dependent on navigation by magnetic polar alignment.  Given the acceleration of magnetic polar axis drift in recent years, we may be on the verge of a reversal, which would pose interesting questions on all sorts of issues, from ICBM navigation to GPS to migrations to at-sea navigation, etc. - and what I found interesting was the speed of the reversal of the spinning objects relative to the amount of time they remained in their original orientation.  A rapid flip gives less time to prepare our systems for the phenomenon and respond.

"The earth won't flip" claim is... interesting to me. As a firm believer in the Scientific Method, let me propose a hypothetical, backed by some degree of evidence, that maybe the earth surface is doing the flip, not the physical core or the magnetic field. I'm no conspiracy person - this idea just seems interesting to me, and it intuitively correct based on the little data we have about the Earth's internals, and I just want to share it.

First: We know something flips. It's either the Earth's surface or the Core, since we have evidence going back the on the ocean floors showing the magnetic fields changing:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geomagnetic_reversal

An eyebrow raising detail of the reversals is that they are random.

Consider: The information provided in this video makes it very clear that a body whose mass changed from one axis to the other could induce the Dzhanibekov Effect.

Consider: The earths surface and upper mantle is mostly rigid, or at least certainly more rigid than the inner mantle, or at least more rigid than the fluid layer between the surface and the solid core.

Consider: It is reasonable to assume, and indeed we're getting recent data that in fact, plumes of mantle 'move around' inside the earth.
gradient

indicative
https://www.nasa.gov/feature/nasa-researchers-track-slowly-splitting-dent-in-earth-s-magnetic-field

Consider: A powerful plume or set of plumes arrive into the upper mantel and cool and solidify and stick to the upper mantle. Now you have an inner core which has not had a mass angular momentum change, but an the Earth's upper mantle and surface has. The inner core is mostly unperturbed, but the outer mantel and surface are now newly exposed to the Dzhanibekov Effect. The outer core has gone from rotationally spherical to rotationally tennis racket.

Could it be the outside surface of the earth is what flips during Geomagnetic reversal, rather than the core or the magnetism of the core? It kinda seems more reasonable that the surface flips, because I'm guessing the inner core of the earth is way more massive than the externals of the earth.

Also the randomness of the planetary scale heat plumes - matching those of a lava lamp - would be random. Which is lovely since we even use lava lamps to help us generate truly random numbers:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1cUUfMeOijg

It seems much more likely that the core would be more stable and the lighter outer portions of the earth are what would be flipped.

Let's hypothesize for a moment and say it was the outer surface of the planet that flipped. (north to south) with the core remaining un altered. What evidence would there be to prove that on the surface of the earth? Obviously the magnetic record on the see floor - but that doesn't tell you want flipped, just that the magnetic field changed relative to the surface.

What archaeological evidence would prove the surface flipped? For example, Is there any known archaeological method to know what direction the sun came from? Say like 'Hey at this time it was supposed to be winter here but it looks like it was summer, and stayed that way for a few thousand years'. No - that would be useless, because even if you could, it would be affected by seasons, but they're affected by seasons anyway - you'd have to have precision down to the year across a data set spanning millions. Too little signal to noise ratio no? You could be staring at the archeological showing sun direct data over cycling annual seasons, but you'd have no way of knowing if you were 6 months off.

I'm not currently aware of any method for humans to know aggregate periodic surface angles to the sun with that precision past the time of the most recent flip.

Does anyone else out there know of a way? Even one way will prove this idea wrong.

I'm not looking to criticize the vectors representation on the small point masses, but if they were to represent the acceleration magnitudes, those should've probably been greatest only when the disc would be at 45 degrees from the reference plane and become zero at 0 and 90 degrees. Those look only like instantaneous force or velocity vectors! Indeed, the inertial (or the fictitious centrifugal) forces of the small point masses are the greatest at 90 deg and zero at 0 deg, so they make sense as force vectors, but speaking about accelerations only, at 90 deg there is zero arm to generate any rotating moment about the X axis (if we take X passing through the great masses) and at 0 degrees there's the greatest arm, but virtually zero inertial forces to apply to the small point masses. From this it would make sense to me that at exactly 45 deg, the acceleration is highest (as there's the highest product between arm and inertial forces) and goes towards and reaches zero at 90. This also makes me conclude (if indeed at 45 the acceleration is highest) that the acceleration is a tangent function of the relative angle between the disc and the reference plane. Please correct me if my theory is wrong stating that only at 45 degrees inclination, the acceleration is highest.

This has great implications for all 3 inertial axis objects, such as space objects or even my beloved airplanes=). From this I can conclude that if a fighter plane which starts developing a pitch rate but the Y (wings plane axis) axis is having a high enough offset angle (less than 5 degrees can be enough high) from the real axis about which the whole plane is purely rotating (so not the actual pitch axis), the higher the pitch rate or the higher the offset angle (basically you can think of it as a dot product between them) will eventually make the plane flip-roll 180 degrees. This now validates why I was seeing MIG-29 OVT's or Su-35s unexpected and surely not pilot intended 180 degrees rolling motions half way through a Kulbit maneuver (a fast pitch up rate 360 degrees pitch rotation).

Here is at least one possible example (it may be due to a brief asymmetric lift between the wings as much as for our subject's phenomena) of this non-commanded effect which affects the plane's reactions, similar to the tennis-racket:

Idk how it took so many years to figure this out. I often observed this phenomenon flipping phones, skateboards, and knives. I used to wonder why I couldn't flip things in the air without that secondary rotation happening, despite attempts at trying to correct for what intuitively seemed an error in forces I was exerting. After watching this video, my observations make perfect sense. Seeing the rotation actually matches my new/corrected intuition. Even before getting to the part in the video where they explain how dude was able to describe the phenomenon in a way that would make intuitive sense, I had a hazy idea of it in mind. The idea came from noticing the acceleration and deceleration of the flipping motion. I was thinking it must have something to do with a very slight offset in weight distribution on different ends of the axis of rotation. Unnoticeable in the beginning but due to centrifugal force, exponentially greater. Hence, if you can make an object spin perfectly upon its intermediate axis, it would never flip. The object would probably have to be completely rigid and the flip performed in a vacuum without any other forces acting on it. Something like magnetism or air resistance could make the most minute change off axis and centrifugal force would eventually and exponentially cause it to flip, and the momentum(near insignificant initially) of that spin would carry it back to and past spinning near perfectly on the 2nd axis over and over

The Japanese discovered this a few hundred years ago, I believe. The katana (samurai sword) operates this way ( and the tachi before it, also works this way). This is most likely the reason it's curved and stiff. You don't throw it however (you're only executing the flip portion of this phenomenon): when holding it with one hand, you can take your thumb, place it on the opposite side of the handle and then give the sword a quick push in the the opposite direction you want it to go while, at the same time, flicking your thumb sideways to give the blade spin and then let go of the sword.

A split second later, you grab it again (it takes some practice to figure out the timing but once you get it down, you can do it in basically any direction, easily) - in that amazingly short period of time, the entire two to four pound, 28 inch sword flips and is now pointing in the opposite direction it was a split second earlier. It's takes almost no effort and is one of the aspects of the weapon that made it so terrifying to face: you have absolutely no idea where the strike is coming from. Two samurai could be walking toward one another, holding their weapons one way, and in the quarter step before coming within range of each other, reposition and launch the weapon from someplace it wouldn't have seemed possible.

This technique only works with curved blades. A straight sword won't do this.

However....the longer, flexible swords, like the English longsword, had an ace up their sleeves that curved swords can't emulate.

A 'perfect' rotating sphere with a perfectly balanced mass in space will never flip-over. Since the Earth is not a perfect sphere, and nor does it have a perfectly balanced mass in space, it's possible it can flip-over/reverse poles. It's a 'relatively' stable spheric mass in space (in regards to overall mass distribution from the inner-core up until the outer crustal layer). But what we're really talking about here/what matters to us is the outer/crustal layer. Since it's floating on the middle layer (Magma), it's susceptible to flipping-over/pole reversal. Deep-core ice & rock drilling samples which reveal evidence Millions of years into Earth's past have shown that Earth's poles have flipped/reversed many times in it's past, with regularity. The 'liquid nature' of most of inner Earth (Magma) surrounding the core/mantle and comprising a large amount of Earth's overall mass,  (liquid being in perpetual motion), somewhat helps to counteract the increased frequency of possible flip-over, almost like an 'internal gyroscope' counteracting the 'external gyroscope.' The Earth is also wider, and hence more dense at the Equatorial zone, almost like a spinning top. The question is does this fact mathematically further enhance or decrease it's frequency of crustal flip-over/reversing poles whilst floating on a liquid layer of perpetual motion. Counter-intuitively and going against science as we know it (in regards to spinning masses in space and the 'perfect sphere/mass' theory), it may actually help to counteract the frequency of potential crustal movement.

Fantastic computer graphic showing the equally fantastic explanation by mathematician Terry Tao. This Terry Tao explanation implies that if an object can be spun absolutely perfectly about its intermediate axis, it will not perform the intermittent flipping effect. This phenomenon touches on a far wider phenomenon known as "design sensitivity". Any engineer designing anything has to evaluate the effect on their device of a particular magnitude of change to any of the hundreds/thousands of parameters that make up their device, an example would be an overly touchy throttle where a tiny fluctuation of the throttle produces an unexpectedly large acceleration, or in electrical terms, to much "gain" in the circuit. Some engineers assign "criticality" levels to all aspects of their designs.

As an adjunct mechanical engineering professor, I have been demonstrating this "Dzhanibekov" phenomenon since 2012 in a machine design course I teach (I knew nothing until today about Mr. Dzhanibekov). I use a simple rectangular wooden block from a children's wooden block set and I color coded the sides much like you color coded your tennis racket. Perhaps like you, I was tipped off on this phenomenon by an engineering book that stated that objects spin in an unstable fashion about their intermediate axis. Later I, like you, I stumbled on the first international space station video you showed where an astronaut carefully imparts a spin to a special T-handle causing it to unscrew itself from a panel (maybe you saw this video first). The fact that the T handle spends the first several rotations unscrewing itself is important to this video since that keeps the T-handle aligned such that it "launches" off the panel relatively well aligned to the intermediate spin axis, meaning that it takes many revolutions for the Dzhanibekov effect to initiate and which makes the international space station video look creepy and interesting.

I was unaware of cosmonaut Dzhanibekov and his similar spinning wing nut observations, but there again, because his wing nut had the chance to spin about its intermediate axis in a relatively aligned fashion due to its start on the threaded rod, when it was ejected off of the end of the threaded rod, it took quite a few rotations for this effect to occur and made the effect much more pronounced and interesting to cosmonaut Dzhanibekov.

So, the key point in the Terry tau explanation is that during the flip portion of this phenomenon and for the first 90° of the flip, the lesser masses of the object in the Terry Tau explanation, which are initially centered on the intermediate axis of rotation, experience increasing forces in a direction that promotes the flipping but, and as you pointed out, the critical and fun fact is that for the next 90° of the flipping event, the forces acting on the lesser masses in the Terry tau explanation experience a decelerating force which attempts to realign them to the original spinning position about the intermediate axis at which point the phenomenon starts all over again.

So, The more you carefully initially align the spin of the object about its intermediate axis, and the smaller the smaller-masses are in the Terry Tau explanation, the longer the spinning object will spin about the intermediate axis between flipping episodes.

Ever since I started puzzling over this phenomenon, my mind did not jump to the spinning earth issue that you say so worried the Russians (they probably were also mulling over any military applications of this phenomenon in terms of rotating projectiles including rockets, like the tumbling rocket issue that befell that early USA rocket you talked about), but to tall rectangular sky scrapers. In my mind, I was concerned that if such sky scrapers are being spun by the rotating earth about their intermediate axis, I wondered if there was an unplanned for torque being exerted upon their foundations. The Terry Tao explanation answers this question - yes, there is a torque and the magnitude of the torque is related to the angle of the rectangular skyscraper to the earth's spin axis (would be fun to write out the formula for the Dzhanibekov torque acting for such tall structures). If the rectangular sky scraper is aligned correctly, the torque is zero, but there are other alignments where a, perhaps, measurable torque is generated.

I doubt that building designers know about or account for this torque, but it would be interesting to correlate problematic sky scrapers, for example, ones that experience glass cracking (due to the unplanned for torque on the building) more than other sky scrapers. Or, perhaps the torque on a misaligned sky scraper is small and "not of engineering significance".

On a somewhat related cool physics note, to this day, uninformed people blame the Coriolis force on everything including the direction water spins as it goes down a toilet. Calmer minds have long ago proved that the spin direction of the vortex of water draining down through small household round drains has more to due with the directions of the machining marks left on the metal drain than whether or not you are in the Northern or Southern hemisphere. BTW, there is a funny Simpson's cartoon episode where the USA Australian embassy, according to the cartoon show, installed hydro jets to force the toilets in the USA Australian embassy to spin the good old Yankee way (ha ha).

Thanks again for a thoughtfully produced and well explained video.

The Janibekov effect is one of the reasons why turbulence exhibits the erratic, white-noise-like behavior we all know from our daily practice. This "white-noise"-like behavior is the basis to describe turbulence by means of so-called "Fokker-Planck equations", which are often also called "Kolmogorov equations". They dynamically balance probabilities generated by white-noise-like forces, i.e. where the correlation functions are delta functions. These three bright minds came across with their ideas almost at the same time: Fokker and Planck coming more
from physics, Kolmogorov more from math (maybe Fokker and Planck were the initiators and K. jumped on a running train which he cleaned from "ugly observational trash" so far that clean, charming theorems came up. For details please google UNIVERSAL EQUATIONS AND CONSTANTS OF TURBULENT MOTIONS; see also UNIVERSAL CONSTANTS AND EQUATIONS OF TURBULENT MOTIONS.
One even might say that the Janibekov effect (together with a number of brigtht ideas from other sides) helped to solve one of the last unresolved enigmas of classical physics: For more than a century we humans have had ALL the strict and fundamenal laws of fluid mechanics and of classical physics in general in our well-manicured hands, but could not put these pieces together to PREDICT simply observable phenomenae like boundary layers (airplanes, rockets, submarines ...) to get a simple mathematical exercise which it really is. Obviously it was necessary for us humans to go to space to discover what sits in "boring classical physics" and what also BIG DATA and AI did not discover. The human brain, sitting in our real-world body, trained by our daily life practice in our real-world environmen is still the most powerful instrument the eternal evolutionary process has ever generated. We shuuld accept that this process is sort of a wonder calling our respect.

There's quite a few problems with the argument about why the earth can't flip. First, the example for the argument is cylindrical, not spherical. The two shapes have completely different moments of inertia. Secondly, the examples don't take tidal forces from the moon into consideration, gravitational forces of nearby planets, nor continental drift. Thirdly, the earth has internal energy (a molten core) and external energy (solar radiation) that it has to deal with.
As far as I can tell, we're in no way safe from this effect. Hell, it might even explain why one of the planets in our solar system rotates backwards.

With the Earth and other large, spinning orbital bodies, there is a feedback loop on the moment of inertia. What makes the Earth's moment of inertia maximal at the equator is that is because there is a small, but significant, equatorial bulge. What causes that bulge? The rotation of the Earth of course. So what came first? Did the Earth spin on its current axis because that's where the moment of inertia is maximised, or was the Earth's moment of inertia maximised about the current axis because that's the way it was spinning?
I rather suspect the latter, although it's known that the Moon has a stabilising effect too.
In any event, I would have thought that feedback loop would act to stabilise the Earth's spin.

Cute, but Cartesian axes are not functional in physics. The first law of Inertia evolves to unit identity and the relation with work in Thermodynamics. When you apply work to an axis, it is treated as a wave function transforming toward equilibrium (3rd law). The motion then propagates that wave inefficiently along the intermediate axis. To be clear, the inertial axis and translation axes are linear, but the intermediate axis is angular, a complex entropy axis transforming the wave function toward equilibrium. These are manifold axes, not Cartesian.

Strange?  Isn't this the same set of forces that keeps a rotating bicycle wheel vertical when it rotates?  Its well-known that when you replace tires on your car you have the wheel balanced before taking to the road so that the plane of rotation of the wheel is maintained to a mechanically sound level.  Unbalanced, the wheel will cease to rotate around the desired axis and cause wear on the bearings.  Of course, there's little need to rotate a wheel in space but when you do rotate an object in space alone I would think that one would get a uniform unbalance, balance, unbalance, balance effect because of the near impossibility of having an absolutely perfect mass distribution in any manufactured object.  Correct me if I am wrong, but in a zero g environment on an unfettered, unattached rotating small body, I would think the behaviour is perfectly predictable (though you will forgive me for conducting this "gedenken" experiment and speaking out of turn if that is the case).  I would be at a loss to explain it mathematically, that is true, but I've worked on enough gyroscopic instruments in my days at sea and also in the air that it simply seems we've not broadly extended our prediction of phenomenon to rotating bodies in which there are few external forces acting on it.  Mankind's prediction of the 3 laws of motion was hampered by his observation of motion in a "non-Newtonian" frame of reference and I think this is just some of the same.  Objects on earth would behave the same but they are beset by larger forces which overcome tehh object before this effect becomes visible.

I discovered a different but equally odd rotary phenomenon when I was a nine year old kid in school.
That was back in the days of dip pens, and all school desks had a ceramic inkwell in the top right-hand corner. Those inkwells were a LOOSE FIT in their wooden sockets, so they could be slipped out for filling with ink. Also, a kid could jiggle them about to make a REALLY annoying noise, ìf he had a mind to.
Well, I found that if I put my index finger in the hole in the middle of a dry inkwell, and then moved that inkwell around against its socket in a circular path...

... NOT twisting my finger, you understand, but moving it in a circular orbit, like driving a disc round on a turntable...

... then something very odd happened.

As I moved my finger in a circle - pressing the inkwell against the side wall of its socket - the 'well immediately began a rotation of its OWN. It twisted itself around on my finger, BUT IN THE WRONG DIRECTION, AND AT ABOUT 1/5th MY CIRCLING SPEED.

Yes. If I moved my finger in a circular orbit clockwise, the inkwell would bear against its socket and twist around on my finger, (and in the socket) in an anti-clockwise direction, but slowly... as I remember about 1/5 or 1/4 speed. Anyway, it was certainly always the same proportion of my circular rotating rate.
If I reversed my direction of circling, the inkwell also immediately reversed and went the other way, at that same slower speed.

I hope I have explained this strange behaviour in terms that can be understood.

I have never met anybody who ever noticed this, or gave other examples of it, let alone being able to explain it to me. Even when the Internet came along, I never (not yet) found any reference to it... unless YOU know better, of course.
If you have been, thanks for reading... and if you can add anything to my strange "discovery," please do.

That implies that the 3 axes of rotation are not very clearly defined.  Presumably a few mountain ranges, undersea trenches etc cause the asymmetry that defines the axes.  Which leads to the question - Could a 'small' movement of mass like the melting polar ice caps cause the axes to change order ?  Thinking it through, it seems that we are still safe because losing mass at the poles should increase the angular inertia of the current spin axis.

There is no, nor ever was a Mayan, "End of the world" prediction.

The Mayans recorded time, basically, in complete chapters they called, "Great Cycles". Each one was meant to be a representation of rebirth, not death. One of their calendar systems (and they had a few) was called the "Long Count".

These were recorded as "Great Cycles" that were 5,000 years long. In fact, in the beginning half of 2012, archaeologist and National Geographic Grantee, William Saturno, found a series of numbers painted on the walls at a Maya complex in Guatemala showing a series of calculations for predictions reaching another 7,000 years into the future.

Why did these writings finally stop? Basically, its because the Mayan culture fell apart so no-one was around to write any more.

The bigger point mass in your example will move side to side in the same plain as the biggest moment of inertia. Because it is unstable. This side to side movement causes the small point masses to move in a spiral. As the acceleration grows bigger in the spiral the force on the small point mas grows bigger. When it gets big enough the object will flip over. Initially, the "flip" is assisted by the side movement of the bigger point masses as it moves through 90 deg. The side to side force opposes the "flip" force. Dissipates the "flip" force until it is zero. We are now 180 deg from where we started and our spiral starts again. Like you. This seems like a very overcomplicated solution to a very simple problem. There's three relevant laws of dynamics.
1. There's no way to perfectly spin an object. There will always be a slight "pollutant" rotation energy on the other two axes.
2. Path of least resistance. Objects want to spin along the axis with the least inertia.
3. Gyroscopic force (ie heavy centripetal force along an axis, ie rotational inertia) resists rotational force on other axes.

It's not micro gravity.  It's free fall.  If acceleration due to gravity is 9.81 m/s^2 at sea level and acceleration due to gravity from the earth is 8.73 m/s^2 at the space station, then it is not micro gravity.  The only thing that is missing on the space station is the normal force from objects pressing back due to gravity, hence it is free fall.  This is why your apparent weight is 0 N.  No normal force.

Anyone not sure why the wing nut still flips after being stabilized by the bolt, I have an explanation: At the very end of the bolt, where the thread terminates, is a single point where the thread is flush with the end of the bolt. 180 degrees away from that, it is not. So as the wing nut reaches the end, there is a moment right before the wing nut frees itself completely that the thread is applying force to only part of the wing nut. This uneven force just as it makes that last turn off the bolt, induces a slight wobble.

Take your spinning bicycle wheel: It really wants to maintain a fixed orientation.
Now, take something (the wings on those nuts, the center post from that T-handle) and it adds a third axis of rotation that is in tandem with the primary rotation but extended outward from the center of rotation. As the wheel spins, that third balance begins to oscillate and, when it reaches a point where it's rotational torque equals or exceeds the rotational torque of the primary axis - it flips. It looses rotational energy when it flips and allows the primary axis to regain it's rotational stability... for a short time, as the third axis of rotation balances and begins to oscillate again...

After replying to Chris McCabe I considered it was worth a larger audience,
so here it is again for those who don't bother with reading the Replies.

Richard P Feynman was an excellent lecturer however discovery was not his talent. Now this Effect is still not properly understood by Everyone 30 years Later. His auto response was both wise and humble at the time. His disposition was wonderfully positive and humorous, where he never claimed to be a Mr Knowitall (W.Somerset Maugham). I hope Derek didn't mean to demean the great lecturer as he did and in hindsight of the many passionate responses would've worded it differently. But getting back to the science, After 30 years I seem to be the Only Person who has taken this effect to the next level.

Let me explain.
In '92 I independently noticed this Anomaly (Like thousands of others) during my self funded experimentation between moonlighting as a plumber. I was already 5 years into developing my own Unified Theory Of Everything. Though I shelved it, I kept going back to it. By '96 I'd proven the pole shift was not due to aerodynamic forces, as another had commented previously, but was proportional to it's mass density and spin. Shelved it again. By '03 revisited it and showed a Theoretical Physicist friend of mine, who again wasn't aware of the phenomena and encouraged me to continue. Finally after showing this Effect to over 100 people I made some headway when approaching UniMelb Mech Eng. Dept. in 2010. The Prof. tried reciprocating the effect on their simulator to no avail!
Well that was a rush in itself. A good feeling knowing my gut was on the right path to pursue understanding the effect. After seeing me throw a steel tetra in the foreyard outside his office, he gave me a students instruction on Mech Eng, which he authored and told me to get back to him with the results.
Well 8 years later I finally got around to forking out $4,000 and three more models later produced what you see on the Video today. Unfortunately the Prof had retired or moved on and trying to find the right people who had the qualifications to verify my findings isn't easy. It's not your average problem!
Well 6 months after publishing my experiment at my utube channel along come Derek with a good knowledge of the past history of attempts at identifying and quantifying this Effect, which is why I'm here. See prior to the moment Terry Tao was commissioned to work out the math I had already worked out it's relationship with Solar Mass's and proceeded to publish the findings in my 2nd Edition of the Periodic Table which was to incorporate the G.O.O.D Theory and introduce a new Law of Physics P = ms . That in itself was drama, was rorted another $4k by a rogue who called himself a Graphic Artist and resolved to shelve the second edition and reprinted the original '97 copy instead, due to lack of funds and the need to replenish stock.
Well you could imagine my outrage when I was only just recently humiliated by the Morons at MathOverflow by informing their community of my Verified findings prior to their 'Golden Boys' so called work of Genius!
Well after all that Math and 8 years later the very same Morons still Failed to recognise nor identify what I had done 20 years ago and professionally verified 9 years ago. 1 year prior to Tao's commission!

Now thats Arrogance for you. Their argument was that at Math Overflow only direct answers to the problem (regarding whether it can be expressed using Eulers method) can be posted.
Regardless my abstract correction of added information (8 years after the original post mind you) was just way too much for certain autistic impatient moronic mathematicians.
Well I don't expect that attitude will change in the near future. Universities have been designed to compartmentalise and keep the bigger picture disclosed for Adept Use Only!

So getting back to this Effect, I as much if not more than Dzanibekov have every right to put my name behind what I not only Independently discovered but spent time, money and a lot of effort to identify what NO ONE ELSE has yet done to date!
So in all fairness, since not a single One of these Brainiacs could or have added one bit of understanding to this Phenomena since Feynman, I would expect that Derek would at least show a little respect to a better man and, apologise for such a remark.
Come on Derek, you can do it!
A bit of humility is good for the soul.

This is misleading though. You make it sound like the twisting must occur whenever a object with 3 axes of inertia is rotating along its axis of intermediate inertia. You say, "... there is virtually nothing you can do to stop it." But at the time mark of 8:22 of the video, you clearly explain that the twisting happens BECAUSE its rotation is NOT perfectly aligned to the axis. This is what you say, " ... what if the disc is bumped, so that it is no longer rotating perfectly about the Y axis." That is when the twisting will occur. In other words, the twisting doesn't necessarily occur whenever it is rotating along its axis of intermediate axis, like you seems to be saying, but it is only conditioned on the fact that the rotation is NOT perfectly about that axis. And we can clearly see that when you throw the tennis racket or the phone. You are NOT throwing it perfectly "straight" and the racket or the phone is ALREADY slightly twisted when it leaves your hand. If this is the case, the phenomenon isn't really as bizzare at all like you are saying.

One of the best explanations I've seen, but you could have said even more. Because of its spin, the earth has an equatorial bulge; points at sea level on the equator are 21.3 km farther from the center of the earth than sea level points at the poles. (Mt Everest is only 8.85 km high). This greatly increases the stability of the earth's rotation. The poles do move, mostly in a circular motion with peak amplitudes of a few hundred meters due to redistributions of mass in the mantle, oceans and atmosphere (including melting glaciers) but otherwise the spin is quite stable.

The planet Jupiter, which is almost entirely fluid, has an even more pronounced equatorial bulge because of its very fast spin.

The fluid dynamics of the earth's liquid outer core and massive solid inner core have rotational instability due to the equatorial bulges of both the crust/mantle and the solid inner core. Like the mantle, the inner core is also an oblate ellipsoid and rotates within the liquid outer core slightly faster east than the crust/mantle. This raises the prospect of an inversion of the inner core independently of the crust/mantle . It also suggests that magnetic field reversal (in the magnetic outer core) could be a consequence of the physical inversion of the non-magnetic inner core .

The earth's crust/mantle has a 26000 year period of its 23.5° wobble. If this wobble is spiraling (to or away from its wobble-pole) then it could well result in a slow flip of the earth over in a just few more wobble cycles (50,000 years). Likewise, the magnetic (outer core) pole is drifting north west relative to the earth's surface, while the earth's inner core has a 60 year period of rotation east in a 10° wobble relative to the earth's mantle. However the magnetic north pole is (geologically) accelerating north west at high speed and if the Dzhanibekov effect is thrown into the mix then a model could be devised showing the earth is indeed entering a period of high instability of its magnetic field due to interactions between the eccentric inverting inner core, the magnetic outer core and the rotation of the mantle.

This is not just a likely scenario. Almost every large object in our solar system revolves and rotates in an anti-clockwise direction. Uranus however has an almost horizontal (98°) inclination off the vertical making it either a rare clockwise rotation or inverted and just over half way through an inversion cycle. Venus is completely retrograde (clockwise) suggesting it has re-stabilised in the inverted state. Pluto sits at 120° or 60° retrograde. All the other planets have about 25° wobble except Jupiter at 3°, and only Mercury has no significant wobble (0°).

This is visualised In the following link - as each planet tilts from the vertical to its current axis it unintentionally shows what is going on, albeit on a geological timescale --> https://youtu.be/GY6Pya_0OuU

An easy and fun way to experience this effect is tossing a cereal box.  Three orthogonal axes, the mass of the box symetrically distributed around each axis of three.  Toss it in the air trying to spin it only about one of the axes.  Practice just a little and you'll be good at spinning it only around one axis.  However,  you will find that you can successfully spin it in stable rotation around two of the box's axes, but there will be one of the three axes around which, try as hard as you will, and practice all you want, the box simply will not spin in stable rotation. Here is my Layman's Way of explaining the Dzhanibekov Effect:
(1) When an object is rotated along its least stable axis (of rotation),
(2) it tends to "flip" along its most stable axis,
(3) and it will "flip" in the opposite direction of any wobble it has along the remaining axis.

How dos this relate to inertial coupling, the effect that caused (or contributed to) the loss of the X-2 in 1956? My understanding is that if an aircraft is rolls "off axis (i.e. the axis of roll is not down the "long axis" of the aircraft, the ends will tend to accelerate outwards - that's OK on most aircraft with long wings, where the acceleration of the wings counters the off-angle acceleration of the nose and tail. With an aircraft like the X-2 where the wings are stubby and thin (and light), the acceleration of the nose and tail overwhelms that of the wings, causing the aircraft behave like the T in our little experiment, and if not damped by the empennage and control surfaces, the aircraft can violently swap ends, just like our spinning T-handle.


I thought that effect was pretty well studied by aerodynamicists in the mid-late 1950s - in fact Mel Apt was working on that exact problem until he was killed in the X-2, and the same affect nearly killed Chuck Yeager in the X-1A in 1953.

[Comment updated&reposted 8Oct)]The fluid dynamics of the earth's liquid outer core and massive solid inner core have natural stability yes, but can be forced into an unstable response by an external disturbance. That disturbance could be nothing more than a small 26000 year wobble, which the Earth just so happens to have. If this wobble is spiraling (to or away from its wobble-pole) then it could well result in a slow flip of the earth over in a just few more wobble cycles (50,000 years).

This is not just a likely scenario. Almost every large object in our solar system revolves and rotates in an anti-clockwise direction. Uranus however has an almost horizontal (98°) inclination off the vertical making it either a rare clockwise rotation or inverted and just over half way through an inversion cycle. Venus is completely retrograde (clockwise) suggesting it has re-stabilised in the inverted state. Pluto sits at 120° or 60° retrograde. All the other planets have about 25° wobble except Jupiter at 3°, and only Mercury has no significant wobble (0°).

Planetary inversion is a real phenomenon, that can happen in at least the extreme circumstances demonstrated by the Russian cosmonaut. There is certainly not yet enough evidence to claim that this can not happen, or has not happened, to the earth. So why would anyone assert that it hasn't or cant, if the truth is that nobody actually knows? That position amounts to a belief, not science, and because of the gravity of the situation, I prefer to believe it can happen. Show me some better evidence than a specious 1980's theory offered up by the propagandist Russian government.

So, can we apply chaos theory here? In Tao's simulation with the different point masses, the disc will only flip if there is a small bump. That means the tiniest of instabilities in the beginning of the spin will grow into big instabilities that cause the unusual flip. Therefore, it may be possible to spin something on the 2nd axis, as long as it remains completely stable. But that complete stability on the 2nd axis may be near impossible to achieve. Since even a single atom more or out of place on one side of the axis would be an inherent cause for instability. So, for a perfect 2nd axis spin the object must have an equal mass distribution around the 2nd axis and each atom must be identically placed to its corresponding atom on the other side of the axis. Angular momentum is I omega. That is, it is the moment of inertia times the angular velocity for the axis about which the object is spinning. The angular momentum is constant because there are no external torques acting on the body. So if you compare angular momentum about the different axes, you get:


H = I_1 omega_1 = I_2 omega_2 = I_3 omega_3


Now the angular kinetic energy is 1/2 I omega^2. That's very analogous to linear kinetic energy, 1/2 m V^2.


Notice that you can substitute the constant angular momentum into this equation for angular kinetic energy. You get:


KE = 1/2 H omega


H is the constant angular momentum. So this lets you see why the kinetic energy is greatest when spinning about the axis with the minimum moment of inertia, because that has the highest angular velocity. And when you spin about the axis with the maximum moment of inertia, you have the lowest spin rate. So that gives you the lowest kinetic energy. That's why the body will always end up spinning about that axis if there is any way for the body to dissipate energy.


The flexible antennas on Explorer 1 did that. Any wiggling of the original spin axis caused those antennas to flex. as they flexed, they reacted moments back into the body and those moments change the angular velocity of the body. It's almost like a precession caused by those tiny moments acting on the body if you think of that body as being separate from the antennas. And similarly, the reaction moments acting on the base of the antennas caused them to wiggle. So the bodies and the antennas interact and drive each other whenever there is wobbling of the spin axis.


The flexing makes heat and the heat radiates out to space. So the original kinetic energy gets converted to heat and the body ends up spinning more slowly about its axis with greatest moment of inertia.

Just a little nitpick... you mention "microgravity". While this is a common term, the gravity experienced by astronauts is almost full Earth gravity. Things just float about because they're in freefall, constantly falling. It's like being in a falling lift, in a long enough lift shaft things would seem like they were floating. Or in the "vomit comet" aeroplanes like in this video, where the aeroplane dives and it seems like gravity is switched off.

In orbit, a spacecraft is constantly falling, pulled toward the Earth by gravity. It's also constantly moving forward, with the inertia from the movement it's engines gave it during launch. If you just launch a rocket straight up, it falls straight back down again. So rockets tilt over and start moving sideways, at 90 degrees to the Earth, then start moving that way.

So they fall at the same speed everything else does. It's just that when they've fallen, say, a metre, they've also moved forwards a bit. Enough that the Earth's surface, being round, is a metre further beneath them. This keeps going, through inertia, Newton's first law, keeping the craft moving forward, and gravity keeping that inertia from sending the craft off into deep space. The gravitational pull and the forward movement are in balance.

(I realise Mr Veritasium knows this)

Point is a lot of people, as I used to, think there's just less gravity in space, cos it's too far away from Earth. That's not the case. "Freefall" is a much better description of what's going on, and just the phrase explains a lot. I think it would be good if science educators used the phrase more, "zero gravity" and "microgravity" are misnomers. It's less effective gravity, but the same thing happens to anything that's falling. Since that is what's happening.

Interesting! I noticed this behavior many years ago as a kid, trying to figure out and understand certain skateboard flip tricks. I have no formal physics education, I just like to think about things… but it seems to me that there is a hierarchy of stability in rotational axes, where mass = stability. In the disc example, the 4 points of mass rotating around Z is always the most stable, with the least amount of inherent wobble. And comparing the X and Y axes, where there is mass on the axis line, the one with more mass on the axis line will always be the most stable. So in this example, Y, the intermediate axis, is the weakest of the 3 rotational axes, because there is less mass on the Y axis line than there is spinning around it (on the X axis). This allows centrifugal forces to cause the wobbling mass on the Y axis line to run away from the axis, and thusly to rotate around the next strongest axis in the hierarchy, which is X.
Ultimately though, it should come down to uneven weight distribution and wobble. In theory, under perfect conditions, an object could spin around the intermediate axis without flipping... An absolutely perfectly symmetrical object, with perfectly uniform density, in a zero gravity vacuum, spun perfectly on that axis without the slightest amount of wobble, would rotate without flipping. But we can't create those conditions, so I think there will ALWAYS be a wobble in ANY object’s rotation, which is why this effect always occurs.
Also, why do you say that centripetal force is the only force acting on the mass points? Isn't that incorrect? I don't believe that centripetal force actually draws mass inwards, centripetal force is simply the amount of force required to resist the outward pull of centrifugal force, is it not? Centripetal force is not the same as gravity.

Here is the intuitive explanation for the flip: it is the the sum of a remainder of an unbalanced equation inherent to the mathematical model of the spin NEARLY around 2nd axis but not precisely.
You missed a piece of the puzzle about the Earth flipping. You assume no exogenous energy added into the system to compensate for the dissipation of kenetic energy into heat, etc. that happens when spinning the bottle of liquid solution in space. Introduce a laser to heat the water inside the bottle, and see if it flips. However, the evidence of magnetic poles reversing comes from the frame of reference of the Earth itself (magma rock formation), so if what occurred was a complete flip of the earth, it would not affect the polarity of magma-iron laid down on the Earth. The frame of reference (iron heavy compass "North") and the object (the magma flows) would remain unaltered. However, if you consider that the earth may have a core with different moments or inertia than it's crust, AND that the layer in between is a fluid layer which is not homogeneous in mass-density, etc., it is certainly possible to construct a model where the core flips inside the Earth!

This theory would be supported if the magnetic pole reversals occurred during the span of a constant number or rotations. So if you zoom in on every flip, and model the amount of magma spread in a single day, you would find the time to effect a magentic reversal would be relatively constant. (I revised this part after watching more closely some of the slo-mo videos of stuff, but someone who has actually dealt with the math of astral bodies can reply to this comment with what the duration of the flip would be a function of).

The explanation of Terry Tao, although it seems clear, but in fact it is not. Indeed, the reasoning given to explain the instability of rotation around an axis with an “average” moment of inertia can be applied in exactly the same way to rotation around an axis with an “least” moment. But, however, the rotation around the axis with the smallest moment is stable. This means that the explanation is untenable.
