Before I even reach the halfway point of this video, here's my hypothesis:


Of the rotating handle with 90-degree lever arm at the center, there are two forces at play:


First lets assume the rotating body is rotating on the X-Axis and that the origin is at the midsection of the long section of the handle.
Lets call the rotating body a "handle"
Lets call the long section of the handle "Side A"
Lets call the smaller and orthogonal section of the handle "Side B"


The object is spun about the X-Axis which cuts through the center of Side B and Side A.


In an Ideal environment
1. Side A will continue to rotate about the X-Axis due to it's angular momentum unless disturbed by another force.
2. Side B will also continue to rotate about the X-Axis due to it's angular momentum unless disturbed by another force.


Realistically however, it is impossible to have the X-Axis cut perfectly down the center of Side B and Side A. All it takes is for the axis to be off by less than a micron for turbulence to ensue.


Because of this; Side B is not in perfect rotation and will eventually accelerate away from the X-Axis once it has built enough angular momentum to overcome the angular momentum of Side A.


Once this Side B angular moment overpowers Side A angular momentum, Side B will cross over to the other side of the X-Axis.


At this point, the angular momentum of Side B will have momentarily dissipated and the angular momentum of Side A will once again take over the system and then the phenomenon will continue as if in a never ending loop, unless the handle is acted upon by another force.

Its not as complicated as your explaination.
We know that when an object with 2 masses rotates in any axis then the centrifugal force of each mass is always parallel to each other. There are 2 condition of alignment:
1) The centrifugal forces are perfectly aligned to each other.
2) The centrifugal forces are not aligned to each other.

In condition 2 the tendency of 2 centrifugal force is to aligned to each other due to the bending created by each centrifugal force to each arm from the center point of rotation. When each masses reached a condition where each centrifugal force are aligned it will not stick to that perfect alignment because there is a momentum of each masses that make is pass the perfect condition aligned condition. This momentum put the 2 masses in a pendulum effect so it will go back and forth to alignment then non-alignment condition repeatedly.

I suggest you to study the pendulum effect in a rotating masses. That is the reason why it is hard for you to understand the characteristic of a rotating body. Uh... I'm a little confused why the host states that he is going to try to explain this, then passes up the obvious example for a simple explanation.

And the visual for this simple explanation is right there in his video.
Watch the spinning "T" handle with a steel shaft at 5:14 in this video.
( https://youtu.be/1VPfZ_XzisU?t=314 ).
The object is spinning about the axis which passes through the shaft, but not perfectly. It has a slight “wobble”.
The “wobble” will start to magnify due to the nature of centrifugal force, as can be seen by the spiral shape the end of the shaft draws in space. This spiral continues to enlarge until the force of the “wobble” overpowers the inertia of the “T” shape, at which point THE SHAFT becomes the greater point of inertia.
However, the rotational inertia is not alone. It also comes with linear inertia.
I don’t understand the math, or which terms to use, but simply said, the linear inertia is pushing the shaft toward plane in which the "T" is spinning, and when the “spiral” falls directly in line with that plane, the linear inertia keeps pushing the shaft “forward”, which is the FLIP this video is attempting to explain.
And it continues to happen because the imaginary “spiral” continues, but now it is decreasing in size.
Eventually the decreasing spiral approaches zero, but the same imperfection which caused the centrifugal force to start the spiral to begin with, will cause the spiral to miss a perfect alignment with the shaft, so the spiral starts to increase again, and the cycle repeats.

The tennis racket and cell phone flip over  because when they're flipped, the hand doing the flipping unconsciously induces a spin.  It's nearly impossible to throw something without spinning it.  Things spun mechanically will flip because of their inherent imbalance.  One side will almost always be slightly heavier than the other and, when spinning, the heavier side will in time induce it to flip.  If a perfect, uniform density sphere is spun, it will not flip.  If any other uniform shape of uniform density is perfectly spun on any of its three axes, it will not flip.  In short, if the thing being flipped begins its spin exactly through its precise center of mass, it won't flip.  Or course, when something is flipped in air, the air will act on it to throw it out of balance.

Here is a neat real-word physics thing I observed. For kids to play on, there was a disk on a good bearing set into the ground. These playground things usually have a set of bars to hold onto but this one was a simple flat disk about 6 feet across. If you spun it up and the put a basket ball on the surface, the ball would roll along, spinning faster as it approached the edge as if it was about to fling off as you might expect but instead when the ball was rolling as fast as it could, it would steer away from the edge, slowing and moving toward the center. It would then begin again to fall towards the edge, speed up and steer back toward the center and slow down. Cycle repeated till the disk slowed down. Ball would not fall off the spinning disk. I have no idea how to math out what is going on but it happened and I will never forget how amazing it was.

you can do a trick similar to the tennis racket flip: take a pair of solid metal scissors that have been loosened to where they are almost sloppy on their axle. hold the scissors by the blades, closed.
1. toss them upwards to about head height, giving them a slight flip so that they flip over once and you catch them again in the palm of your hand. easy, get the hang of that so you consistently can do one flip and they land flat in your palm.
2. now when you do the flip, give the scissors a spin along the long axis so you make them do one flip and one twist before landing flat in your palm.
3. Now do it again but harder so you get 2 or 3 flips & twists before landing. And then you'll see the cool part, the scissors will open and close 2 or 3 times while in the air and land closed, flat in the palm of your hand. You will get the 3rd axis spin without trying.
you should now also have a good feel for the balance of the scissors, try throwing the scissors like a dagger, you should be able to stick them in a drywall sheet from any distance!! (Be careful, Don't run while holding scissors and, ask your mom before throwing scissors, sticking them in your bedroom walls.)

What's even more interesting about this, is the motion of the 'flip.' How does it conserve so much momentum during this?
From the outside, it has the same direction of rotation throughout it's linear path. But from the perspective of the object, rotation comes to almost a full stop before it tumbles, then it proceeds to rotate in the opposite direction; essentially from the perspective of the object, the motion is forwards and clockwise, then a tumble, then backwards and anticlockwise.
There seems like there is also a lot of momentum conserved here if an object can do multiple flips.


This is also a great example of just how imperfect our universe is. What works on paper doesn't always work in practice. No better way to show this than a wobble induced by the smallest of forces that aren't detectable with our own eyes.








Now for other things.


Looking at the perspective of the object, could we actually use this as a design implementation for space travel? Rather than having multiple smaller 'reverse' thrusters, you could induce a roll, flip the craft around, stop the roll, and use the main thruster as a brake. I know spacecraft are much more complicated than any object demonstrated in this video, but the working principle could make it possible to do this with a more complex object, right?
Something like this would be interesting for a constant takeoff and reentry vehicle. Say it's conical with a dished bottom. It'd be aerodynamically efficient for atmospheric takeoff, and doing the flip would make reentry possible, and could use the thruster for landing. This would reduce the amount of auxiliary thrusters needed for maneuvers like braking and flipping the nose and tail to opposite sides. I know this isn't the best example, but lets say the craft approaches reentry with it's nose before flipping, to make this a valid use case of the concept; which would also work in the case of traveling to multiple bodies, whether they have an atmosphere or not.
I know this is a lot of what-if's, speculation, ideas, and science fiction since we don't have a space craft that can take off without massive amounts of thrust and fuel. My structural engineering prof actually covered this in class (in 1989, so before that paper). The analogy he used was to a ball rolling on a sinusoidal hill. If the ball is placed at the very top of a peak or the exact bottom of a trough, the slope is zero so it is stable and stays there. These correspond to spinning about the maximum and minimum moments of inertia. But if you place the ball in between either of these points, it will try to roll towards the minimum, overshoot, head towards the maximum, not make it, come back down to the minimum, overshoot, repeat.


Same thing goes on with a rotating body. It wants to rotate around the minimum or maximum moment of inertia, so it starts trying to change its rotational axis to match one of these axes. But when the two match, the rate of change of its rotational axis s non-zero. So the rotation axis carries past that stable axis (overshoots), causing it to again end up rotating about a non-stable axis, and repeating the cycle.


While the third axis orthogonal to the maximum and minimum inertia axes is the most obvious, the same thing will happen if you rotate it around any axis which isn't the maximum or minimum. (Analogous to starting the ball at any point on the hill other than the maximum, minimum, or the midpoint between those two.)

That doesn't explain anything. Firstly, with liquid, it is not system with 3 free way of motion (3 rotations). Liquid is not rigid body. Btw, angular momentum is vector, and kinetic energy is scalar. And, if kinetic energy always decrease (which result in stop of rotation eventually), how can then angular momentum still have some value?
My explanation, with thinking about 10-15 mins, is something like this. Both angular momentum and kinetic energy change, both decrease. In same way like, when you let some amount of water (or some other viscous fluid) in some channel or pipe. Little forces on particles from viscosity will decrease velocity gradually and whole momentum. And that same forces times dx (Work) will decrease kinetic energy, which will go in temperature. But why it flips to rotation of biggest angular momentum? Because liquid can move, and because of centrifugal forces, goes furthest as possible from axis.

My physics professor’s ( Mario Freamat PhD. )response to my email when i had sent him a link of the astronaut’s video 9 months ago. Hi, Zagros.
Nice find.
The clip illustrates a classical result of the rotational dynamics of an object with three unequal axes of symmetry (like a rectangular block of uneven sides), called the "intermediary axis theorem". It is more like a corollary of the model describing the rotation of an object as a set of coupled rotations projected about three rectangular axes of symmetry. It states that, while the rotations about axes parallel to the largest and smallest sides are stable under small perturbations, the rotations about the intermediary axis will be unstable. That is, if the object is spun around axes parallel with the larger and smallest sides (like the length and thin height of your mobile) and the rotation is slightly perturbed, the perturbation will remain a stable precession. Yet, if the rotation is about an intermediary axis (like the width of the mobile), a perturbation will be amplified and the object will flip the axis while rotating. The cause is that the moments of inertia (that is, how the mass is distributed about the axis of rotation) about the three axes are unequal, with the one about the intermediary axis in the middle. The math is not immediate, but it can be shown that the character of the perturbation is given by the differences between these moments of inertia. For each axis, the difference involved is between the moments about the other two, such that the difference will be positive when the rotation is about the intermediary axis, and negative otherwise, which changes the physics of the equations describing the perturbations: exponential growth about the intermediary axis vs. harmonic precessions about the other two. You can try to observe the phenomenon for yourself by tossing your mobile rotating in the air above a safe surface: note how the rotation is smooth when about the long and thin sides, but wobbly when about the intermediary side.
The object in the video clip also has three axes of symmetry, and note that the astronaut spins it about the intermediary axis. The object would spin smoothly if the astronaut managed to put it in motion exactly around the respective axis of symmetry, but he didn't, so the rotation is perturbed from start. The perturbation is amplified until the axis of rotation is flipped. After the flip, since the rotation is still perturbed due to inertia, the axis is again flipped. Because the experiment is in conditions of levitation, the motion looks like an oscillation of the spin. Otherwise, if done in normal conditions, the flip would be harder to observed because the object would fall to the ground.

Hey Derek and rest of the internet,

It's an awesome video but I run into 1 problem with YOUR explanation (not the mathematical one).
An good, intuitive and logical explanation has to be self-consistent.
That is precisely where I run into a problem, let me explain:
For reference I'm going to use the example you explain at @7:10
So as you state we have the 1st axis or x-axis; 2nd axis or y-axis; and 3rd axis or z-axis.
This goes from lowest to highest moment of inertia.

Now your explanation is completely logical and understandable when we rotate around the 2nd axis.
However I would then expect the same to happen to the first axis as this should result in a similar result if we assume that no object "realistically" ever spins perfectly around it's axis. So in that case the heavy point masses would also be tilted slightly off-axis and would in turn also result in a "flipping" effect similar to how it does around the 2nd axis. The main difference in that case would be that the period/frequency of flipping would just be different, maybe an other of magnitude, but it wouldn't make it 0 nor infinity.

Don't get me wrong I really love to have an intuitive explanation but it needs to then be self-consistent.
Maybe I'm missing something or overlooking something, that's possible. However after discussing it with a friend of mine we both came to the same conclusion.

Hopefully I missed something but otherwise the explanation needs adjusting and unfortunately we still won't have an intuitive/logical explanation (which is the main point of the video).

Best regards,
A fervent watcher of your interesting educational videos

NOW I UNDERSTAND WHY, in 2010: Odyssey Two, the American Discovery spacecraft was windmilling when the Russians in the Cosmonaut Alexi Leonov arrive at Jupiter!!! The Dzhanibekov Effect explains so much about what was going on, and how when the rotation of the spinning carousel (to simulate gravity for the astronauts on the Discovery) slowed to a halt, that spinning motion around the X-axis of the Discovery ultimately converted to a windmill rotation around the Y-axis of the ship. Here is how I came to think of it after spending a while thinking about it when I saw my first intermediate axis book flip demonstration in my classical mechanics class.

Both momentum and kinetic energy need to be conserved. They can't appear or disappear.

The major axis rotation has highest angular momentum to kinetic energy ratio, while the minor axis rotation has the lower angular momentum to rotational kinetic energy ratio. There is no other axes of rotation that can conserve these two quantities, so they must stay stable near those axes.

Around the intermediate axes, you are not at a minimum or maximum for either of those quantities. There are an infinite number of solutions, a small percentage of which are tumbling solutions that require the object to turn around. Since most of the solutions that preserve these quantities are near the intermediate axis, it looks like it spend most of its time stably rotating about the intermediate axis, but its really shifting through those possibilities in the process of turning through the slight end over end rotation that leads to the tumble and is imparted by imperfection in the original orientation.

Angular momentum is not conserved. Imagine a gun firing a bullet in space,  at a railway sleeper. It fires the bullet, angular momentum is zero. It hits the sleeper,  not in the middle, but towards one end. Suddenly we have rotation, and angular momentum. What was a zero sum system now has a gun travelling backwards, but not rotating, and a sleeper, with a bullet in it, rotating. No conservation, there.

Great video, loved the animation. However, this logic implies that the same effect would occur when the mass rotates about its axis with the smallest moment of inertia. Some important details are missing - namely, the Coriolis force. When you are in a rotating frame you must account for both the Centrifugal force (proportional to mass and the distance from the axis of rotation) as well as the Coriolis force (which increases with mass and velocity, and acts in a direction perpendicular to both the velocity and axis of rotation). Basically, when you rotate about the intermediate axis, the Coriolis forces are negligible because they are proportional to the small masses, and pushing the small masses in a direction perpendicular to their motion and the axis of rotation requires the large masses to move as well, while the Centrifugal force only requires the small masses to move. Therefore the Centrifugal force dominates and you get the effect explained above. Now, when you rotate about the axis with the smallest moment of inertia, a small perturbation of the large masses (which are now along the axis of rotation) results in a Centrifugal force as well as a  Coriolis force, just like before. However, this time the both the Coriolis force and the Centrifugal force are proportional to the large mass, and it is no problem that the Coriolis force requires the small masses to move as well, because they are negligible compared to the big mass. The effect is that the Coriolis force is large enough to move the masses in a direction perpendicular to their motion and the axis of rotation. A force that stays perpendicular to the direction of motion results in circular motion. So basically, the Coriolis force is able to turn a small perturbation of the large masses into a small circular motion about the axis of rotation, and it doesn't let the Centrifugal force dominate, which would result in the flip.

In aviation, the three-axis of an airplane are similar to the axis of the tennis racket.    The first is the "longitudinal axis" which runs from the nose of the airplane to the tail.  The second axis is known as the "Lateral Axis" which runs from one wingtip to the other wingtip.  The third is the "vertical axis" which runs from the roof of the cabin through the bottom.  The rotations of the airplane about the three-axis are known as "roll", "pitch" and "yaw" respectively.  I'd be interested in seeing if an aerobatic airplane with super-strong wings would react the same way as the tennis racket if the pilot were able to "snap" the airplane into an immediate "accelerated stall" in the pitch-up attitude and see if it performs similarly to the tennis racket.

I'm by no means a physics expert. Even the explanation was difficult to follow, but I thought I'd mention the perspective I had before learning of this video's explanation. Maybe it that might add context to visualize it better.

5:15 When the "T" shape rotates, the wings spin counter-clockwise. Even though the entire T flips, the wings still spin CCW to our perspective. That means the entire T is flipping on the axis that runs between the wings (which doesn't change the axis where the wings are spinning from) . But what is making the stem of the T flip like that? It only flips after a certain amount of turns, meaning it has to be a progressive force that keeps building in magnitude until it shifts the balance of the stem around. It's a weak amount of force or torque who's effect is smaller than the primary spinning axis, because it flips less than the T spins. Because it does not inhibit the spinning, and it always shifts back and forth consistently without destabilizing, it has to be a balanced and constant force that doesn't loose energy.

In other words. This flipping is stable and continuous so it must be a natural result of the object spinning, think as though it's shifting its position like it's taking the least possible 'path' of resistance. If the stem of the T is slightly destabilized, then it's like knocking a top or a gyroscope off center, where the spin starts to pull it apart, only this time there isn't a table to stop it from flipping and pulling itself back together.

Great explanation, but one error at 8:20: You claim that in the rotating frame, the outward centrifugal forces are balanced by the inward centripetal force, but in the rotating frame, the object is stationary, so there IS no centripetal force. (Symmetry: if there is no centrifugal force in the inertial frame, then there is no centripetal force in the rotating frame.) The inward force balancing the outward centripetal force is just the structural support (strain) of the disk itself. When the smaller objects are perturbed off axis, then there is no analagous restoring force from the disk, so the motion is unstable.

That wobble will eventually propagate into a flip with only enough energy to overturn the object a single time...and repeat

It was my understanding that centrifugal force was a bit of a misnomer.

My understanding was that there was really no such centrifugal force pushing masses away from an axis of rotation, each mass simply wants to maintain is vector motion perpendicular to the face of the disc.
The centripetal force being the force that pulls it around into circular motion toward said axis of rotation (the center of the disc).

If one of these masses were to detach, it would fly out on a trajectory perpendicular to the face of the disc at the moment of release, instead of directly away from the edge (centrifugal).

Is this understanding incorrect?

the graphic at 10:10 is incorrect, the direction of the earth's rotation should stay the same, due to conservation of angular momentum. if you watch closely, the wingnut flips orientation, but it's direction of spin is always the same, which has to be true since angular momentum must be conserved.


an interesting implication of this is that in the process of flipping over, there is a fraction of a second where the wingnut actually stops spinning around it's intermediate axis before it begins spinning around the intermediate axis in the opposite direction (which produces the same angular momentum since the orientation has flipped too). a similar effect can be observed in slow motion footage of a tippe top

The tennis racquet phenomena and the rotating wing nut, although related, are not the same. The tennis racquet has one-half flip for every rotation. This explanation appears to address the wing nut but NOT the tennis racquet.

Though it may not count, I think this has similar properties to spinning a Tippe top; you may use the stem to initiate the momentum of its rotation, but it will always flip to spin on that said stem until it slows down.

The similarities are;
a. 1 direction of spin and inertia (in the wingnut, away and parallel to the bolt, for the top, gravity)

b. the distribution of its central axis of balance (irregular wing nut and the top-heavy Tippe top design)


My hypothesis; the smaller the ratio of differences of the object's central axis of balance (from a wingnut to a bead), the higher the frequency of its flips (ie. the least stable its rotation along its axis) in zero G.

I appreciate your videos a lot. I thought I might just add that in reality, and contrary to public opinion, 'centrifugal' forces don't pull objects directly away from the centre of rotation as you say at 8:15. If you cut a hammer thrower's line, the hammer would not suddenly take a 90 degree turn directly away from the thrower - there is no force applied to do it. Instead it just carries on in the same direction as it was already going until a different external force is applied. Yes, the hammer thrower thinks that the hammer is imposing a force away from him, but that's only because the line is taught. Therefore the idea of centrifugal force is only 50% true when you take components of force into account. Maybe you could do a video on this!

There's an easier explanation. Think that things are imperfect - you'll never have pure rotation along one axis only.
Spin on the "heavy" axis, and imperfection would give a little spring to the "light" axis. But the light actually is too light to have an effect.
Spin on the light axis, and it's so light that it's easy to make it spin very fast, and fast things don't change easily (angular momentum).
Spin on the intermediate and it's easy to give spin to the light axis that it becomes unstable.

I can see complications with planets and this effect!
You can think of a planet as being a point source of gravity with a revolving hollow sphere of crust. Because of the rotational energy being transmitted to the crust it will tend to have a greater radius at the equator than the poles! This means that the spin imparts energy to counter gravity at the equator ...... but this is a function of the spin and gravity. Alter the spin or the gravity and it is unstable.

On a solid planet there would be no problem , but the earth’s crust is floating on a somewhat liquid core of magma .... which is floating on a more liquid core of iron!

We know the magnetic effect of the spinning liquid iron (or maybe the solid centre) is moving! This means almost certainly that the inner core is altering its axis of spin! We also know that the Pole star (true north) has historically not been in the same position! This means that over time both the inner and outer parts of the globe have been spinning at different axies! Unless there is a self protecting effect happening it means that we may well have some interesting times ahead!
Weather us humans are still around to witness this possibility is moot!

Maximum moment of inertia. Fun fact: When I was in the USAF we had to measure the Maximum Moment of Inertia(via a hanging Sway Test) of every bomb type that was planned to be tested on the B2 Bomber during it's initial flight testing phases. They needed to know how much time it would take for the flight control surfaces to stabilize the flight of the falling bomb when it was released. Each bomb only has 2 lugs holding it to the bomb rack(one forward and one aft) and they don't always release exactly at the same time. Only takes Milliseconds to induce an inertia pitch or yaw.

After mulling this over for a bit, I realized there's an issue with this explanation: as stated, it seems to apply just as well to the principal axis with the smallest moment of inertia. For a complete intuition, you would need to understand why it DOESN'T happen there. I believe the answer to that question will probably center around the coriolis force on the 'flipping' mass, and how the torque from that affects the primary rotation. That torque should be small in comparison to the primary rotation's angular momentum in the intermediate axis case, but large in the smallest axis case.

I would bind a book into a "solid" with rubber bands and spin it about the max and minimum moment axes and then challenge a friend to spin it about the intermediate axis and of course it tumbled out of control. So, it flips over because of its minute instability on one of its axis. The thing is, nothing tells us that there is absolute stability on the other two axes, and they never flip over on those axes. Against my own thinking, if the object seeks stability by rotating about an axis where it has maximum moment of inertia, nothing says that the object sought stability about one axis where the masses around it are equally distributed, so the moment of each segment of mass keeps changing while constantly seeking their own axis. The dominant one pulls the largest which results in oval shape locus. Just like the earth going round the sun, its oval. Its the principle of conservation of energy that can be used to satisfy Kepler's law. The earth is for sure not balanced, or at least no one can be sure of that. As for the wing nut, it calls for a lab experiment to create a perfectly balanced wing nut, spun around a ball bearing and see its behaviour. And for the liquid bottle, we should bear in mind that liquids change their centre of gravity with acceleration, all because it constantly is in the state of convection and different densities co-exist.

The "intuition" in the video is fatally oversimplified. It makes no mention of why rotation around the intermediate axis behaves differently from rotation around the smallest-inertia axis. It may have a hint, but it is hard to spot. The math makes it very clear, but the video glosses over it. The math, starting from scratch, is complicated. But if one accepts the 6 Degree of Freedom Equations of Motion, the math to prove this requires just one derivative and one substitution. So from that starting point, the math is not as hard as the video implies.

Any ideas on why the flip takes place in space over a short span of time, almost like a phase transition, while on earth it seems to be more of a continuous transformation?
My guess is that it has to do with the fact that the space station reference frame is continuously free-falling. If we were to do the same experiment on earth, but to move along the same accelerating reference frame as the object which is spinning about its intermediate principle axis, would we see the same result?
A second guess would be the lack of air currents which could cause additional perturbations that lead to the chaotic motion we see on the earth experiment. On earth, as the object is flipped, air is rushing past it since it is falling or rising in air.
A third guess would be that the way that the torque is applied about the intermediate axis for the objects in the space station is guided by the screw itself. So if I attempt to flip my phone about its intermediate axis, I may be easily introducing additional perturbations along other principle axes. The fact that the objects spin in the space station is initiated by spinning the object around a guided axis of rotation (such as spinning a wing nut about a threaded rod) provide torque that is more precisely aligned with the principle axis.
Thus: If the third hypothesis is true, nothing should be stopping you from seeing this strikingly fast spin flip in an experiment which can be conducted here on earth. If you had a slow-mo camera, you could get a wing nut and place it on a horizontal lubricated screw. Then you could spin the wing-nut off the screw and let the wing-nut fall to the ground. If you go high enough, perhaps you can see the effect in slow-mo. I'm guessing that the air currents (hypothesis 2) will cause problems, and you will end up needing to put the system under vacuum. This would be really cool to try, if possible.

The tennis racket theorem is so idiotic it blows my mind that some scientists actually take it seriously. All that's happening is the forces you apply to the racket (or anything else) when trying to rotate it in air lengthwise aren't perfectly balanced and make the racket rotate like that. Any small offset of where the force you apply is center on the object you're throwing will make an object not spin in air in a balanced way, it's obvious. Build a machine that will rotate the racket PERFECTLY balanced, and it will not make a half turn in air.  In fact, you can do it by hand as well if you practice enough. How do I know?  Played tennis for almost 20 years. I've probably spun a racket like that a thousand times. And just to prove the point, I just did it with my phone like 6 times in a row after getting a hang of it and finding the right way to throw it.

Incidentally: gymnasts convert forward/backward flip inertia into twisting inertia using a very similar method. When they are "flipping", they are spinning along the axis with the most moment, and to twist all they need to do is "change shape" enough to transfer some of that kinetic energy to the 1st axis. I'm not exactly sure it qualifies under the same theorem or problem though, as gymnasts are inherently non-rigid shapes and it becomes more of a controls theory problem. However, the bleeding of momentum from one axis to another is definitely the case.

This is a great video! However, I would argue for an easier, and much older, explanation to the Dzhanibekov effect based on the Binet ellipsoid. It Turns out that in the body frame, the rotating frame of reference that exhibits the centrifugal forces, angular momentum can be used to form the surface of a sphere and the kinetic energy can be used to form the surface of an ellipsoid (A 3D Ellipse). Since in the torque free motion of a rigid body requires that both angular moment and kinetic energy must be conserved, then path of the motion, technically the angular momentum vector in the body frame, must lie on the intersection of the ellipsoid and the sphere (See GIF). It can be seen that the intersections form closed ring motions (i.e. stable rotations) around the axis with the smallest and largest moments of inertia. However, around the intermediate axis the intersections do not form closed circles, they cross all the way around the ellipse indicating that the motion is unstable and flips back and forth periodically. So the reason that the instability arises is because these two "competing" quantities (Angular momentum and Kinetic energy) must both be conserved at the same time.

Here is a GIF and Video to show visualizations.

GIF: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/79/Intersecting_ellipsoids.gif
Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ei79Y_aqrm0

Bruce Yeany (look him up, he's on YouTube) has a lot of physics toys for his students. Among them are a lot of complex pendulum arrays. As soon as I saw the footage in this video (which I'd never seen before), it reminded me of their behaviour. When you have a pendulum mounted on a pendulum, movement will "transfer" from one to the other. One pendulum will move quickly while the other remains fairly still for a while, then they flip rapidly and the opposite happens.


My instant assumption was that the same is happening here. The bolt (or racket) is spinning in both axes because nothing is perfect, but in the more stable one predominantly. After a while, balance flips to the other axis, causing the bolt to flip, before switching back. The underlying physics is absolutely fascinating, but you CAN demostrate a similar phenomenon by tying a weight on a string and tying another weight on a string off of that.

Maybe it's just me, but it seemed dead obvious, intuitively, what was going on. Rotating on that intermediate axis makes the object's position on the minor axis unstable, so that a tiny nudge in any direction on that minor axis will be accelerated until it rotates completely around that axis at least once (the system needs to lose energy so that the initial nudge isn't carried over to jump start another rotation).


If you could toss the racket absolutely perfectly (in a vacuum so you don't have to worry about eddies in the air), it would rotate only on the intermediate axis. Give it the slightest nudge after that, though, and it would do at least one rotation on the minor axis.

Rotating energy is not the same as kinetic energy. A rotating body does not need to “dissipate” energy to change the axis of rotation. As the angular velocity changes, the angular momentum changes proportionately. The energy state of the system is the same. That is the same principle as a figure skater when they pull their arms in or out.

What I also like is how your goal is to find an intuitive explanation. This is what Feynman was really good at. Einstein I would argue did the same thing as well. If you can understand something intuitively than two things are possible. First, you might be able to use it in normal life and second, it makes the more complicated scientific and mathematics understanding more accessible to those working at the highest levels. Einstein didn't start with complicated mathematics and worked backwards, he first visualized. Imagine anyone prior to Newton even knowing where to begin thinking about gravity in more than a practical sense. With gyroscopic precession I think what I observed in a judo demonstration in a Japanese high school was a practical application of gyroscopic precession (without understanding the concept). A student spun his arms which turned his body to his left allowing him to plant his right foot and keep his balance. Had I not pursued finding an intuitive understanding of gyroscopic precession I'd have never spotted it.

I'm partial to this (somewhat abstract) geometric explanation:

In the rotating frame, write down the equations for conservation of energy and angular momentum, in terms of the three principal components of angular velocity. Each of those equations describes an ellipsoid in angular-velocity-space, and the angular velocity vector must lie on the intersection. Now think about how two concentric ellipsoids can intersect.

If the energy is nearly as low as possible for a given momentum, (energy ellipsoid is small), they will intersect at two tiny circles along the axis for the largest moment of inertia. The angular velocity vector will precess around the tiny circles, barely changing. If energy is nearly as high as possible, they will intersect at two tiny circles along the axis for the smallest moment of inertia. But in the in-between case, the ellipsoids intersect at two large circles in a sort of double X shape, running all the way around the ellipsoids. The angular velocity moves along from one side of the ellipsoid to the other, which is a flip!

The tennis racquet theorem is pretty interesting, it shows exactly why pro players serve the way they do:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uyTtZE6LSek (play at x0.25 speed)

Notice how they swing the racquet face-closed (almost like trying to hit the ball with the frame) and only open up the racquet face at the very last milliseconds before they hit the ball.

This seems counterintuitive at first but as this video explains, with the racquet face closed, it rotates along the "3rd axis" with the maximum angular inertia and greater stableness, therefore generating maximum power, whereas an open racquet face means it rotates along the least stable second axis with less angular inertia, therefore unable to generate sufficient power.

There's a more intuitive method for understanding the flip. It lies in the periodicity. Musicians will understand. If you try to play two notes at the same time on a brass instrument, your lips will vibrate at both frequencies provided that they are harmonics of one another. That is, your lips will vibrate at C, then at G, Then at C again, and so on. You will not be able to control the duration from an equal rhythmic phasing. It is really no different than using a sum of sine waves to crate a more complex wave-shape - its the manifestation of the sum of the energy at the various points in time (just over 3 dimensions instead of 2). Since the rotation is equally unstable on both sides of the wingnut, the energy has no choice but to rotate equally with whatever periodicity is inherent to the distribution of forces. Arithmetic is not required for understanding this, only for predicting it.

L=Iω <<Angular Momentum = (Moment of Inertia)*(Angular Velocity)>>

Feynman is still right. This explanation is incomplete. It does not explain why there is so little wobbling of the rotating mass.
The explanation says that small offset of the small masses causes centrifugal forces that flips them. However we observe that the object is mostly rotating without visible increase of these offsets, we don't see the masses rotating into higher and higher offsets (wobbling), the whole flipping is kind of done into a single rotation.

It's obvious that there is some balancing of powers and threshold that has to be passed so the small masses centrifugal forces are able to become big enough to flip the object.
To really understand this phenomenon, we need to understand where the threshold comes from.
